physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington c/o Manager, Lloyd’s Bank 67 Kingsway London W.C.2, England. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have just received a letter from Winifred from Zermatt in which she speaks of having just received "Legends" which had been following her round from place to place. As I sent your copy to 1 South Audley Street at the same time I sent hers, in her care, I wonder whether by any chance your copy is travelling round after Winifred and she has not received it to forward to you. That would only matter because I should not like you to think that I did not send you off one of the first copies I received. My allowance from the publisher all came at once, and I sent off my presentation copies together, so, if you have not received yours and it does not appear on the hall table at 1 South Audley Street, let me know and I will forward another.

From Winifred’s letter, I should imagine that she was having an exact but belated honeymoon. She gives me no news whatever about anybody or anything except Robert, which is quite as it should be. That does not leave me thoroughly up to date as to your plans and adventures. Where are you, my dear, and what are you doing, and when is Holt bringing out your book? I have heard nothing more of that either. Mrs. Russell tells me that she wrote you telling you that I had had to have a fourth operation and that she also sent the letter to 1 South Audley Street, but, as we have had no answer to that either, I imagine you have not received any of these things.

My news is of the meagrest description. The surgeons informed me in April that I had to have another operation at once. It was set for the 17th of May, as my friend Mrs. Ayscough, with whom I am collaborating in my Chinese poems you will remember, arrived from Shanghai with a batch of poems to be fixed, and Houghton Mifflin decided to print the book in the Autumn, so that meant a great rush to get everything done before my operation. However, we finished it, and I then had the operation from which I am now slowly and rather discouragingly recovering. Since then I have done nothing but try and get well, and, as I have seen nobody, I have absolutely no news, but that makes me all the more avid to hear some of yours, so do write as soon as you can and tell me how you and Perdita are and what you are doing and everything. I will not write any more now, partly because I am tired and partly because there is really nothing to say.
body.closer: Much love, my dear, from us both. Affectionately yours,
